Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: ABI Innovation: Rapid, Interactive, Visual Mining of Biological Motion
Award.AbstractNarration:
Across the biological sciences, high-quality, high frame-rate images and video are widely used in analysis of sub-cellular organelles to individual organisms. The use of video has become so pervasive, that many research teams accumulate much more data than can be reasonably analyzed by current methods. This project will develop algorithms to allow the rapid and affordable mining of very large video sets for motion behaviors of interest in the study of the collective behavior and emergent properties of complex systems of organisms. This work is motivated by the needs of domain experts in various areas of biological motion analysis and incorporates research in computer vision, image processing, user interfaces, and visualization. A key part of the project is a fast, semi-automated biological object tracker that leverages the computational power of off-the-shelf hardware and incorporates simple user interactions to dramatically improve tracking accuracy in the types challenging cases that frequently arise in biological image analysis. Domain experts will be able to search motion databases through visual query by selecting an example motion of interest. The system will be evaluated on three biological research applications: honeybee behavior, ant colony networks, and cell motion analysis.

Groups of organisms can display a rich and sophisticated behavioral repertoire and are able to make complex collective decisions. Studying these interactions provides insight into collective decision-making, adaptive networks, and division-of-labor. Understanding these complex interactions over large time scales requires new methods of data analysis that this project will address with an interdisciplinary collaboration between biologists and computer scientists. The outreach components of this work include demonstrations and explanations of the complex behavior of groups of organisms and how these behaviors can be studied using computing. The system is intended to be widely-applicable and will be disseminated to other researchers by making the software available for download online.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed a novel approach to automated tracking of biological objects on video, as well as transforming interactions between biologists and computer scientists, and bringing research on complex systems to a broader audience.

Advances in computing power over the last decade have made it feasible in principle to automatically analyze large volumes of video data; however, for biological research to capitalize on these advances, a tool with the end user in mind had to be developed. The ABCTracker, the principal outcome of this project, is a new software, developed now in prototype and ready for professional implementation and distribution. It has an easy graphical interface and requires no programming experience to use, allows the tracking of large numbers of individual ants or other objects such as cells, robots, bees, or termites, with high accuracy of ~85%-95% (of individuals * frames correctly tracked), and a sophisticated and efficient guided or manual correction step. It is the first such tool, will be freely available, and can be used for research or teaching at all levels.  Bringing modern information technology, including image analysis, to classrooms is vital to stimulate interest in and begin training of future generations.

The ABCTracker was created through a close and constant interaction of expert users with developers, thus emphasizing users not as a problem but as the end goal in software development: for example, high emphasis was placed on accuracy, the types of evidence that users of tracking algorithms find convincing, and the need for an option to make manual corrections. The participating biologists in turn provided extensive testing, feedback, raw material, ground truth (manually tracked) data, and initiation of software distribution to a series of labs. As a result, the project also generated a library of useful data to test future innovations in tracking algorithms.

The part of the project located at the University of Arizona helped train 2 postdoctoral researchers, 6 graduate students, 22 undergraduate students, and 3 high-school students; all of these were trained in professional skills (such as the scientific method, writing and presentation, statistical analysis etc.) as well as relevant biological research techniques and concepts; importantly, all also learned specifically through the interactions in this project what goes into software development, how progress in computing and information science is separate from implementation as useable software, and how difficult it (still) is to implement in a computer the abilities that even simple brains appear to have. These, along with the insights for computer scientists about the needs of professional end-users, are non-trivial insights that are now likely to propagate through the respective fields and will improve many future biology-computing interactions.

Using the ABCTracker developed here, this project has already produced a large, rich dataset on social insect behavior, which has been used to answer questions about collective organization, such as emergence of group-level personalities, the role of inactive workers in groups, and the dynamics of interaction networks and their role in division of labor. This research has attracted international attention (eg. from NPR, BBC, Science et Avenir, Sueddeutsche Zeitung and many others), in part because of its applicability to many of our modern societal processes and engineering applications (including in social networks, distributed computing and management). One goal and outcome of this project was to bring such results to more diverse audiences, which was done for example by publishing in the Journal of Bioeconomics and interactions with a consultancy firm and journalists, particularly ones focusing on such topics as the study of organizations. The project also engaged with the public at many ‘live’ venues such as science festivals and school lab tours.
